blocks.text: In these next three sessions we are going to lean into the second core value of “BLESS” and how our identity in Christ flows into a deep, missional love for the world. “Loving our neighbors” in our mission statement is all about our horizontal relationships with people. We are going to discover God’s purpose for His satisfied children to bless the world through our roles in our families and in our spheres of influence.

items: Loving God → We desire to BE God’s satisfied children, love Him, and glorify Him.
And our neighbors → We desire to BLESS others where we live, work, and play.
Together → We BELONG to a welcoming spiritual family.

blocks.text: As we are overwhelmed by God’s great missional love for us through Jesus, we begin to understand that He invites us into that same mission. Blessing others starts right at home and overflows into the neighborhood and workplace. May we live generously and missionally because God first sent His Son to bless us with salvation.

blocks.text: Summary Teaching
Read the article below by Jen Wilkin called “Our Children, Our Neighbors”

If you asked me the single-most important insight that has shaped my parenting, it would be this: “Children are people.” It seems self-evident… until we remember that children are people. Because if children are people, then they are also our neighbors. This means that every scriptural imperative that speaks to loving our neighbor as we love ourselves suddenly comes to bear on how we parent.

Recognizing my children as my neighbors has impacted the way I discipline them, the way I speak to them, and the way I speak about them to others. It has required me to acknowledge how quick I am to treat those closest to me in ways I would never treat a friend or a co-worker. It has helped make my children objects of my compassion instead of my contempt.
Recognizing my children as my neighbors has freed me up to enjoy them as people rather than to resent them as laundry-generating food-ingesting mess-making financial obligations.
Here are just a few “unlikely” parenting verses that point me back to neighborliness on the days that don’t go as they should:

items: Proverbs 15:1 – When I want to correct with harshness
James 1:19-20 – When I want to lecture
Philippians 2:3-4 – When I want to make them make me look awesome
Matthew 25:37-40 – When meeting their needs feels like an imposition
Matthew 6:3-4 – When I want credit for how hard I’m working
Ephesians 4:31-32 – When I don’t want to extend forgiveness
2 Timothy 2:24-26 – When I’ve lost sight of the forest for the trees
